narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was a superb class. Prof. Weiss is brilliant--and edge-of-your-seat lecturer and a warm and endearing person.

Wonderful class with an engaging and beyond insightful teacher. Creates and encourages the historical analysis of current events that leaves a lasting impact. Readings were occasionally very lengthy, which isn't really an indictment as they were all necessary, just difficult to balance the workload on occasion.

8-12: Professor Weiss is a phenomenal and engaging lecturer and masterful storyteller. The readings are excellent and the course is in my opinion a must-take for all who are interested in food systems and agriculture.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Prof. Weiss. He is the best teacher I've ever had.

Harvey is a fantastic lecturer who managed to weave complex concepts -- capitalism, democracy, diplomacy -- into captivating narratives. His storytelling is remarkable and especially so when he includes stories of his past research and work in the Middle East.
The Professor had a wonderful way of relating the material and using personal anecdotes to further the impact.
The professor's explanation of the readings and background knowledge contributed significantly to classroom discussions. Additionally some of the readings were very interesting.

There were two excellent aspects of this course: 1) Professor Weiss' lectures, especially those covering the reading material early in the semester on the origins of agriculture, as well as his fascinating stories about his time doing archeological digs in Western Asia, and his fine analysis of the region's complex dynamics. They had us all scotched to our seats! 2) The readings Professor Weiss selected for us. Each one of the readings is *absolutely* illuminating.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: None. Except it would be great to do a fieldtrip with Prof. Weiss--if only to the local museum. But Syria or Iraq would be great, too!

Student accountability with the readings was not established at the start of the course, causing frustration that was only voiced at the end of the course. Whatever standard of student engagement Harvey would like from the students, should be set as early as possible. However, also note that Harvey's lectures are phenomenal and the classes he could lecture in full should not be diluted with student insight.
I would say less intensive reading. Although as alluded to prior, the reading is necessary and beneficial, just difficult to balance.

The dates for when assignments were due including grade breakdowns should have been updated and finalized at the beginning of the semester. It was nice that the professor was flexible with when the students wanted to submit take-home exams and other assignments; however, it did cause confusion towards the end of the semester. The last minute assigning of an in-class presentation and decision to only require half the class to submit the final paper was unexpected. If these had been decided earlier on in the semester that would have been fine, but it did not feel respectful of student commitments and expectations to make these changes towards the end of the semester.
I can't think of anything major. The courseload at the end--final paper and final exam is a bit heavy, but I learned a lot so I am happy about it.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Great, also donuts and coffee really helped.

The readings often felt too lengthy for students to complete in one week. As such, it seemed many were unable to complete them prior to class. This resulted in less student participation in discussions. Additionally, it was often difficult to decipher whether the professor was asking a rhetorical question or one that he wanted a direct answer to. I believe this also contributed to less participation. To address this, the professor could better focus the required readings for the class so that it is at a manageable amount, and then perhaps require an in-class presentation on the week's reading as a quick way to review what the readings covered, answer questions students might have had, and encourage increased student participation during discussions. The format of the in-class presentations we had at the end of the semester was fine. But perhaps send around a schedule on one of the first days of class to have students sign up for one or two days they would like to lead the presentation of the day's readings.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As a student interested in global food systems, this class provided the historical reasoning to how and why our food systems are the way they are today.

I thought it would have provided more context than it did. The focus on the history of agriculture was fascinating; however, falling behind with lectures and readings towards the end of the semester reduced the amount of time we discussed modern-day agriculture, a topic I was looking forward to most this semester.

I had been in the process of deciding whether to orient my remaining studies and my future career on building a sustainable agricultural system, or working on clean energy, and this course swayed me to the former!! It was foundational for me. It gave me an excellent and pretty comprehensive introduction of the key elements of the evolution of agriculture, from its origins over 10,000 years ago to present. I initially did not think that the long historical overview would be very helpful but it was so fascinating, that I am delighted to have taken this course. It reinforced to me how central agriculture is to our humanity, thus enriching my view of it and deepening my desire to dedicate my career to this topic.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to get an over-arching perspective on the impacts of environmental issues on human history. I got it.
I enrolled in this course to gain a historical framework when discussing global food issues today.
Interest. Rave reviews of the Professor.

I thought it would provide interesting insight into the history of agriculture, which it did. However, I wish we had spent more time on modern-day agriculture models to better fit the widespread academic interests of the students.

I wanted to decide whether to focus on clean energy or sustainable agriculture systems, and thought this course could help me re-engage with the latter topic and give me a good historical overview that could be helpful in thinking about future sustainable agricultural systems.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Far exceeded them. The course fundamentally cultivated an appreciation for archeology, anthropology, and human history I never had before.
This was my favorite class this semester and so far at Yale. In content it exceeded my expectations and in teaching, it was taught by one of the best. Harvey is fantastic.
Yes, I am ever more terrified at the current state of agriculture and it's potential trajectory.
Kind of
Most definitely! I learned a lot of fascinating and essential elements that give me a comprehensive understanding of what agriculture is all about.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take this course. If you take no other course at Yale, take this course.

Try to do as much of the reading as possible even if you can get away with not doing all of it. The necessary lessons will come out in the midterm and the final but its best to have a grasp on the theories with the corresponding lecture.
Be prepared to read, bring donuts.

I would highly urge anyone interested in food and agriculture to take this course! It is a must take. Professor Weiss is a truly engaging Professor, an expert in his topics, and a clear orator and masterful storyteller. All the readings are excellent and the exam format (take-home) are an excellent way to digest and make your own the course material. You will come away with a fascination to agriculture and an understanding of how essential it has been and continues to be to humanity!
